What to Do

Apply proven design practices, patterns, and principles to avoid many of the vulnerabilities introduced by poor design choices.

Why

Adopting security design guidelines can help reduce your attack surface by addressing common vulnerabilities, and gives you the benefit of learning from others' mistakes to ensure that your application is secure from the start. This frees you to focus on the unique aspects of your design. 

When

Apply security design guidelines during the architecture and design stage of the development life-cycle.

How

To apply security design guidelines for use in your project:

  1. Establish guideline quality requirements. Each guideline must meet the following qualifications before it is included:

    • Actionable. Must be associated with a vulnerability that can be mitigated through the use of the guideline.

    • Relevant. Must be associated with a vulnerability that is known to affect real applications.

    • Impactful. Must represent key engineering decisions that will have a wide ranging impact.

  2. Identify relevant categories of vulnerabilities. Design guidelines are organized by the following common application vulnerability categories, which represent  key areas for application security design where mistakes are most often made:

    • Input / data validation

    • Authentication

    • Authorization

    • Configuration management

    • Sensitive data

    • Cyptography

    • Exception management

    • Auditing and logging

  3. Identify application-specific guidelines. Depending on the application being designed, the types of issues that must be addressed vary. For example, when you design a secure Web application, it is important that you follow guidelines to ensure effective user authentication and authorization, to protect sensitive data as it is transmitted over public networks, and to prevent attacks such as session hijacking. When you design a secure, smart client application, the set of guidelines changes to address the most important threats for this application type.

  4. Identify deployment considerations. During the application design phase, review your corporate security policies and procedures together with the infrastructure on which your application is to be deployed. Frequently, the target environment is rigid, and your application design must reflect its restrictions. In some cases, you may need to make design tradeoffs, for example, to accommodate protocol or port restrictions or specific deployment topologies. Identify constraints early in the design phase to avoid surprises later, and involve members of the network and infrastructure teams to help with this process.

  5. Prepare the security frame. Distill the set of guidelines into a pattern-based security frame, or framework, that describes all of the areas in which poor design can lead to security vulnerabilities. The security frame lets you include additional guidelines or refine existing guidelines based on newly discovered vulnerabilities. The security frame is a pattern-based information model that defines a set of security-related categories specifically for the application type you are designing. These categories represent the areas where security mistakes are most often made. This link helps understand the security frame in more detail.
